content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Santiago Martinez: I was born in Lisbon, Portugal, to a family that valued education and hard work, even though we didn't have a lot of money. My father worked as a mechanic, and my mother was a nurse, though she only finished high school. When I was 16, my family decided to move to the United States in search of better opportunities, and we settled in Newark, New Jersey. It was a big change for me, and I had to learn English quickly. I remember feeling out of place at first, but I was determined to make the most of it. I worked part-time after school to help my family, but I never stopped studying. I eventually earned a graduate degree in business, which helped me land a full-time job in finance. I met my wife, Maria, while we were both working at the same company, and we got married a few years ago. Life hasn't been easy, but I've always believed that with perseverance, you can build a better future for yourself and your family.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Santiago Martinez: Yes, there was a moment that changed everything for me. After we moved to Newark, I was working two part-time jobs to help support my family while going to night classes at a community college. I remember one evening, after a long shift at a local grocery store, I was walking home through the rain, exhausted and wondering if I was making the right choice. I had just received a letter from the university in Lisbon offering me a scholarship to study business, but I knew my parents couldn't afford to send me back. That night, I sat on the steps of our apartment building and made a decision: I would stay in the U.S., work harder, and find a way to earn my degree here. It wasn't easy, but I enrolled in a local university, took on more responsibilities, and eventually got into a graduate program. That moment of clarity was the turning point—it showed me that I had the strength to create my own path, no matter how difficult the road was.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Santiago Martinez: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. It felt like the universe was giving me a sign that night, you know? The rain, the exhaustion, the letter in my hand—it all came together to make me realize that I couldn't wait for opportunities to come to me. I had to take control. I remember telling myself, 'If I don't fight for this, who will?' That decision wasn't just about my education; it was about my family, my future, and proving to myself that I was capable of more than the circumstances I was born into. I didn't have a lot, but I had determination, and I used that to build something better.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Santiago Martinez: Absolutely, I think I was lucky to have a few people who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. My mother, for instance, was the one who encouraged me to apply for that scholarship in Lisbon. She didn't know English well, but she wrote the letter herself, translating it from Portuguese to English with the help of a neighbor. That meant the world to me. And then there was Mr. Alvarez, my high school teacher, who saw something in me and helped me get into the community college. He even gave me a few books on business and finance, which I still keep on my shelf. I don't think I could have made it without those small acts of kindness. Organizations, too—like the local community center, which offered free tutoring and career counseling. They helped me navigate the system here, which was completely foreign to me at the time. I've always believed that no one should have to face challenges alone, and now that I'm in a better place, I try to pay it forward whenever I can.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Santiago Martinez: Yes, I have a partner—my wife, Maria. We met while working at the same finance company here in Newark, and we've been together for almost six years now. She's from Brazil, and we both understand what it's like to leave everything behind in search of a better life. We got married in a small ceremony in the park, just the two of us and a few close friends. We don't have children yet, but we're hoping to start a family in the next few years. Maria is a teacher, and she's been incredibly supportive of my career and my goals. She's the one who keeps me grounded, reminding me that success isn't just about money or status—it's about love, family, and being there for the people who matter most. I wouldn't be where I am today without her.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the key moments that shaped my life. From recounting my journey from Lisbon to Newark, to the pivotal decision I made under the rain, to acknowledging the people and organizations that supported me along the way, it all came together to show how far I've come. Talking about my family, especially Maria, reminded me of how much love and support have been essential in my success. It wasn't just about hard work or making the right choices—it was about the people who believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself. These topics reminded me that my story is not just mine alone, but a reflection of the community, relationships, and opportunities that helped me build a better future.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Santiago Martinez: My immediate family includes my parents, my younger sister, Clara, and my father's brother, Uncle Joaquim. My parents have always been a source of strength for me, even though they faced their own struggles. My father, despite only having a high school education, always encouraged me to pursue knowledge, and my mother, though she didn't have much formal education, taught me the value of compassion and hard work. Clara is 18 now and is studying nursing at a community college here in New Jersey. She's been my biggest supporter, and I admire her courage. She's the one who helped me navigate the complexities of the U.S. healthcare system when I was first trying to get my foot in the door in finance. As for Uncle Joaquim, he stayed in Portugal and runs a small family-owned restaurant. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but whenever I visit, it feels like coming home. He always reminds me of where I came from and the importance of staying connected to my roots, even as I build a life here.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Santiago Martinez: There are a few friends who have been important to me along the way. One of them is Luis, a childhood friend from Lisbon who also moved to the U.S. a few years after me. He ended up working in construction, but he's always been a source of encouragement. We used to meet up every Sunday for coffee, and he'd remind me that I was doing the right thing, even when I felt like giving up. Then there's Elena, a coworker from the finance company where I first started. She became like a sister to me—someone I could talk to about everything, from work stress to family issues. She was the one who introduced me to Maria, actually. Without her, I don't know if I would have met my wife. And there's also David, a mentor at my current job. He's been instrumental in helping me grow professionally and has always believed in my potential, even when I doubted myself. These people, along with my family, have shaped who I am today. I've learned that no matter how far you go, the people who stand by you are the ones who truly matter.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Santiago Martinez: I live in a neighborhood in Newark that's full of character—both good and challenging. It's a working-class area, with a lot of immigrants like myself, and it's not always easy. There are parts of the city that feel run down, with old buildings that need repairs and streets that can be a bit rough around the edges. But there's also a strong sense of community here. People look out for each other, and there are local businesses that have been around for decades. I live in a small apartment near the train station, which makes commuting to work easier. The area has its issues—like high crime rates and limited access to certain services—but I've learned to navigate it. I've also made some good friends here, and there are community centers that offer programs for people like me, who are trying to build a better life. It's not perfect, but it's home. I like to think that I've contributed a little to making it better, even in my own small way.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Santiago Martinez: Honestly, I wouldn't say I feel completely safe here all the time. There are moments when I'm walking home late at night, or even during the day in certain parts of the neighborhood, where I have to be cautious. I've seen things that no one should have to see—drug deals, fights, people getting hurt. But at the same time, I've also seen the kindness in people here. I've had neighbors watch out for me, warn me about dangerous areas, and even help me when I was struggling. I think it's a balance. You learn to be aware, to trust your instincts, but you also learn to rely on the people around you. I don't think I'd ever feel completely safe anywhere, but I've found a way to live here without letting fear control me. It's part of the challenge, and part of what makes this place real.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Santiago Martinez: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, there's the constant hustle—waking up early, working long hours, and trying to make ends meet. But there's also a sense of belonging that I didn't expect. I've met people from all over the world, and that diversity is something I really appreciate. It reminds me that no matter where you come from, you can find a way to make a life for yourself here. I've also seen how the community can come together in tough times—like when the local church organized a food drive for families in need, or when neighbors helped each other during the winter when the heating bills were too high. It's not always easy, but I've learned to find the light in the darkness. This place has tested me, but it's also given me strength. I wouldn't trade my experiences here for anything, because they've shaped me into the person I am today.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people around me and the environment I've chosen to build my future in. Talking about Maria, my wife, made me realize how important it is to have someone who believes in you and supports you through every step of the journey. When I spoke about my parents, sister, and uncle, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for their sacrifices and the love they've always shown me. And when I described my neighborhood in Newark, I couldn't help but reflect on the challenges and the resilience it has taught me. It's not always easy living here, but I've learned to find strength in the community and in the people who stand by me. These conversations made me appreciate how far I've come and how much I owe to the people and places that have helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Santiago Martinez: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though it varies depending on work deadlines and family commitments. I usually wake up around 6:30 a.m., make a quick breakfast, and head to the train station for my 7:15 a.m. commute to work. My job in finance can be demanding, so I often work late into the evening, sometimes staying until 8 or 9 p.m. When I get home, I try to spend time with Maria—we have dinner together, maybe watch a movie or go for a walk if the weather is nice. On weekends, I like to help Clara with her nursing studies, or we might go to a local café and catch up. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading, listening to music, or just sitting on the balcony and thinking. Life here is busy, but I've learned to find balance in the little things—like the smell of coffee in the morning or the sound of rain against the window. It's not always perfect, but it's real, and that's what makes it meaningful.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Santiago Martinez: I work as a financial analyst for a mid-sized investment firm here in Newark. My job involves analyzing market trends, managing client portfolios, and helping them make informed decisions about their investments. I work Monday through Friday, typically from 7:15 a.m. to 8 or 9 p.m., depending on how busy the day is. The hours can be long, especially when we're preparing quarterly reports or dealing with market fluctuations, but I've learned to manage my time efficiently. I also take on some freelance consulting work on the side, which helps me stay sharp and gives me a little extra income. It's not always glamorous, but I enjoy the challenge of solving problems and helping people grow their wealth. I think my background—growing up in a family that didn't have much, moving to a new country, and working my way up through education—has given me a unique perspective on finance. I see money not just as a number on a spreadsheet, but as a tool that can help people build a better future, just like it did for me.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Santiago Martinez: Outside of work and family, I also have a few routines that keep me grounded. Every Sunday, I go to church with Maria and my parents. It's a small Protestant congregation, and it's one of the few places where I feel like I can truly connect with my faith and my roots. The pastor, Reverend Thompson, has been a good friend and a source of guidance for me. He's helped me through some tough times, especially when I was first starting out and feeling lost. I also try to volunteer at least once a month, usually at the community center where I got my first tutoring sessions. It's a way for me to give back, to help others the way I was helped. And on weeknights, after work, I like to cook—mostly simple meals, but I take pride in making something that tastes like home. I learned to cook from my mother, and it's one of the few things that reminds me of Lisbon, even when I'm surrounded by the sounds and smells of Newark.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Santiago Martinez: Actually, there have been a few changes recently. With Clara starting her nursing program full-time, I've been helping her more with her studies, which means I've had to adjust my schedule a bit. I've started waking up a little earlier to have breakfast with her before she leaves for classes, and I've also been spending more evenings at home helping her review her notes. It's been a nice shift—it reminds me of when I was younger and my parents were always there for me. I've also taken up running a few times a week. It started as a way to clear my mind after long workdays, but now it's become a habit. I run along the river path near the train station, and it's a peaceful way to start the day. I think these small changes have helped me feel more balanced, especially with everything going on. Life is always moving forward, and I like to think I'm keeping up.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Santiago Martinez: Well, we don't have children yet, but I think about it a lot. Maria and I have been talking about starting a family in the next few years, maybe once Clara is more settled in her nursing career. If we do have children, I imagine their days would be pretty structured, especially during the school year. They'd probably wake up early, have breakfast, and then head off to school. After school, they'd likely have some kind of activity—maybe sports, music, or something like that. I know how important it is to have a good balance between school, play, and family time. I'd want them to have the same kind of support that Maria and I had, and I'd make sure they knew they could always come to me with any questions or worries. I think I'd also want them to learn the value of hard work and education, just like my parents taught me. It's a different world for kids these days, but I hope I can be the kind of father who's there for them, no matter what.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect deeply on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about my family reminded me of the sacrifices they've made and the love they've always shown, even when times were tough. My wife, Maria, has been my rock, and I'm grateful for her unwavering support. My parents, sister, and uncle have all played a role in who I am today, and I carry their lessons with me every day. When I described my neighborhood in Newark, I couldn't help but think about the challenges it has brought, but also the strength it has given me. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I've learned to find light in the darkness. The conversations also reminded me of the importance of community, faith, and giving back. Whether it's going to church with my family, volunteering at the community center, or simply cooking a meal that tastes like home, these small things keep me grounded. I've come a long way from the boy who arrived in Newark with nothing but determination, and I'm proud of the person I've become. These interviews have helped me see how far I've come, and I'm grateful for every step of the journey.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Santiago Martinez: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty lucky so far. I've always been active, even as a kid—helping out with chores, walking to school, and later, working part-time jobs that kept me on my feet. I don't have any major health issues, but I do have some minor things, like occasional back pain from sitting at my desk for long hours. I've been trying to take better care of myself lately, especially with running a few times a week. I also make sure to eat well—mostly home-cooked meals, which Maria and I both enjoy. I've had a few check-ups at the clinic near our apartment, and the doctor says I'm in good shape for my age. The only thing I worry about is stress, especially with work and helping Clara with her studies. I've started practicing mindfulness and meditation, something I learned from Reverend Thompson at church. It helps me stay calm and focused, even on the busiest days. I guess I'd say my health is a work in progress, but I'm doing my best to take care of it.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Santiago Martinez: What makes it easy to stay healthy, I think, is having a routine and the support of people around me. Maria always reminds me to take breaks, and she's the one who encourages me to cook healthy meals instead of grabbing fast food on the way home. The running has become a real anchor for me—it's not just exercise, it's a way to clear my mind and feel connected to something bigger than myself. But what makes it hard is the stress that comes with work and family responsibilities. Sometimes, when I'm swamped with deadlines or helping Clara with her studies, I forget to take care of myself. I've learned that I have to be intentional about it, to set reminders or even ask someone to check in on me if I'm not being consistent. It's not always easy, but I know that without my health, I can't be there for the people I love or achieve the things I want in life. That's why I keep pushing forward, even when it's tough.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Santiago Martinez: Actually, there wasn't anything major in the past two years, but there was a time when I had a pretty bad flare-up of lower back pain. It started after I spent a few weeks working late almost every night, trying to meet a big project deadline at work. At first, I thought it was just from sitting too long, but it got worse—so bad that I couldn't sleep properly and had to take a few days off. I went to the clinic, and the doctor said it was probably from poor posture and muscle strain. He gave me some physical therapy exercises and suggested I take more breaks throughout the day. I also started using a standing desk at work, which has helped a lot. It was a wake-up call, really. It made me realize that I can't ignore my body's signals just because I'm busy. Since then, I've been more mindful about stretching, taking short walks during the day, and even using a foam roller at home. I guess it's one of those things that you don't think about until it starts affecting your daily life.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Santiago Martinez: Honestly, I've been lucky that my health issues haven't really gotten in the way of my work or family life. The back pain was a setback, but it didn't stop me from doing what I needed to do. I had to adjust my habits a bit, but I still managed to meet my deadlines and be there for Clara. I know not everyone is as fortunate. I've seen people in my neighborhood struggle with health problems that make it hard to work or take care of their families. That's why I try to take my health seriously—it's not just about me, but about being able to support my family and keep going, no matter what challenges come my way.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Santiago Martinez: Over the past year, life has been a mix of growth, challenges, and quiet moments of reflection. Professionally, I've taken on more responsibilities at work, which has been both exciting and stressful. I've been leading a few new projects, and while it's pushed me out of my comfort zone, I've also learned a lot about leadership and resilience. On a personal level, helping Clara with her nursing studies has been incredibly rewarding. Watching her grow into such a dedicated and compassionate person has reminded me of the importance of education and the sacrifices my parents made for me. At the same time, I've been dealing with some personal doubts—questioning whether I'm doing enough for my family, whether I'm making the right choices for our future. But I've also found comfort in the small things: the way Maria smiles when she's cooking, the sound of rain on the windows as I sit with a book, the quiet strength of my community. I think I've come to accept that life isn't about perfection—it's about showing up, day after day, even when it's hard.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines have shaped my journey. Talking about the changes in my schedule, like helping Clara with her studies and taking up running, reminded me of how life is always evolving, and how important it is to adapt. It also made me think about the balance between work, family, and self-care. I used to believe that success meant pushing through without rest, but now I see that taking care of my body and mind is just as important as any other part of my life. The conversation about my health also brought back the memory of that back pain flare-up—a moment that forced me to slow down and listen to my body. It was a humbling experience, but it taught me that I can't ignore my well-being, no matter how busy I am. And when I spoke about the support I receive from Maria and others, I realized how much I owe to the people who help me stay healthy and grounded. These reflections have made me more grateful for the small, consistent efforts I make to take care of myself, and I hope to continue that path with even more intention and care.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Santiago Martinez: I think I've struggled with moments of anxiety, especially during the early years when I was trying to balance work, school, and family responsibilities. There were times when I felt like I wasn't doing enough, like I was failing my parents or Clara by not being able to provide everything they deserved. I remember lying awake at night, worrying about money, about whether I was making the right decisions for our future. But I've learned that it's okay to feel that way—what's not okay is letting those feelings define me. I've started talking to Reverend Thompson more about it, and he's helped me understand that anxiety is a part of life, not a weakness. I also try to stay active, keep a routine, and remind myself that I'm not alone. Maria has been my anchor through all of it, and I've come to accept that it's okay to ask for help when I need it. I don't think I've ever been diagnosed with depression, but I know that mental health is just as important as physical health, and I'm doing my best to take care of both.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Santiago Martinez: For my family, the past year has been a mix of pride, support, and quiet moments of growth. Maria has been my rock, as always. She's been balancing her teaching job with helping Clara with her nursing studies, and she's done it all with grace. I see how tired she gets, but she never complains. She's the kind of person who puts others first, even when she's not feeling her best. Clara, on the other hand, has been amazing. She's taking her studies seriously, and I can see how much she's growing—not just academically, but as a person. She's become more confident, more compassionate, and she's learning to take care of herself in ways I didn't expect. My parents, too, have been adjusting. They came here with so much hope, and while they still have their struggles, they're proud of what we've built. My father, in particular, has been trying to learn more about the U.S. healthcare system, and he's been asking me questions about insurance and doctor visits. It's humbling to see how much he wants to understand this new life we're living. And my mother—she still cooks the same meals from home, even though she's not as strong as she used to be. Every time I taste her food, I'm reminded of where I came from and how far we've come. It's not perfect, but I feel like we're all moving forward, together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Santiago Martinez: For me, religion and spirituality have always been a source of strength, especially during the hardest times. Growing up in a Protestant household in Lisbon, going to church was a regular part of life. It wasn't just about the sermons or the rituals—it was about the sense of community, the prayers, and the belief that there was something bigger than ourselves. When we moved to Newark, I was worried that I would lose that connection, but I was surprised to find a small Protestant congregation here that felt just as welcoming. Reverend Thompson has been a guiding light for me, not just in my faith, but in my life. He's helped me through moments of doubt, reminded me that it's okay to struggle, and taught me that faith isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up, even when you're not sure of the path ahead. I still go to church every Sunday with my family, and I find comfort in the familiar hymns and the warmth of the people around me. It's not always easy to hold onto faith in a place like Newark, where life can feel so heavy at times, but I believe that spirituality helps me stay grounded, gives me a sense of purpose, and reminds me that I'm not alone in this journey.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Santiago Martinez: To be honest, I don't use social media much. I've seen how it can be a double-edged sword—on one hand, it connects people, but on the other, it can also create a lot of noise and distraction. I used to have a Facebook account back when I first moved here, mostly to stay in touch with family in Portugal and some old friends from Lisbon. But over time, I found myself scrolling for hours, comparing my life to others, and feeling more stressed than connected. I decided to take a break from it, and honestly, it's been a relief. I still keep in touch with my family through regular phone calls and text messages, and I use WhatsApp with some of my friends here in Newark. I think it's important to be present in real life, to talk to people face-to-face, and to build relationships that don't rely on likes or followers. I don't want my life to be filtered or reduced to a few pictures—it's too rich for that. I'd rather spend my time cooking, running, or just sitting with Maria and my parents, talking about the things that really matter.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Santiago Martinez: Honestly, I don't think I've ever relied on social media for emotional or financial support. I've always found that kind of support in the people around me—my family, my friends, my church community. When I was struggling with that back pain a few years ago, it was my wife who reminded me to take it seriously, and it was my pastor who encouraged me to keep faith in the process of healing. I think the real support comes from genuine relationships, not from likes or comments on a screen. I know some people find comfort in online communities, and I respect that, but for me, it's the face-to-face connections that matter most. I'd rather talk to someone in person, share a meal, or just sit in silence with someone who understands, than scroll through a feed that might make me feel worse. I guess I've learned that the strongest support systems are the ones built on trust, love, and real-life presence.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about the flare-up of my back pain reminded me of how important it is to listen to my body and not push through pain just because I'm busy. It was a humbling experience, but it taught me that I can't ignore my well-being, no matter how much I want to keep moving forward. When I spoke about my struggles with anxiety and moments of self-doubt, I realized how much I've grown in learning to accept that it's okay to feel uncertain and to ask for help when I need it. I've come to understand that mental health is just as important as physical health, and I'm doing my best to take care of both. These conversations also reminded me of how grateful I am for the support of Maria, my family, and my faith, which have all been essential in helping me stay grounded and resilient through the challenges I've faced.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Santiago Martinez: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually decreased a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've started to find more balance in my life—helping Clara with her studies, running regularly, and making time for the small things that bring me joy. I still have my moments of worry, especially when work gets hectic or when I see how much Clara is struggling with her nursing program, but I've learned to approach those feelings differently. Instead of letting them overwhelm me, I try to break them down into manageable parts. I've also started journaling, something I picked up from Reverend Thompson, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions. When I'm feeling overwhelmed, I take a walk, listen to music, or even just sit quietly with Maria and talk through whatever is on my mind. I've come to realize that it's okay not to have all the answers right away, and that taking things one step at a time is what keeps me moving forward.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Santiago Martinez: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent for our apartment in Newark takes up a good chunk of our income—around $1,200 a month. It's not the most expensive place in the city, but it's still a significant portion of our budget. Groceries come next, especially since Maria and I both cook most of our meals at home. We try to buy in bulk and stick to what we need, but with Clara starting her nursing program and needing more supplies, that part of the budget has gone up a bit. Then there's transportation—my train passes, Maria's bus fare, and the occasional Uber when we need to get somewhere quickly. We also set aside money for utilities, insurance, and a small emergency fund. It's not much, but it helps us feel more secure. I've learned to track every dollar, and I make sure we don't overspend on things that aren't essential. It's a tight budget, but we've made it work, and I'm proud of how we manage it together.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Santiago Martinez: Our household spent roughly around $3,200 last month, which is pretty close to what we usually spend. The majority of that goes to rent, groceries, and transportation, as I mentioned. But there are also other things—like Maria's teaching supplies, Clara's nursing textbooks and lab fees, and the occasional medical co-pay or prescription. We also try to set aside a little money each month for savings, even if it's just $100 or so. It's not a lot, but it gives us a sense of security. I've learned that budgeting is a lot like managing a business—you have to track every expense, know where your money is going, and make adjustments when needed. Sometimes, we have to cut back on things like eating out or buying new clothes, but we've found ways to make it work. It's not always easy, but I know that every dollar we save today is an investment in our future, whether it's for Clara's education, a home of our own, or just having a little more peace of mind.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Santiago Martinez: We rent our home, actually. It's a small apartment near the train station, which makes commuting easier for me and helps Maria get to her teaching job. Renting has always been the practical choice for us, especially with the way things are in Newark. Buying a house feels out of reach right now, not just because of the high prices, but also because of the uncertainty in the market. I know some people in our neighborhood have managed to buy homes, but for us, renting gives us more flexibility. We can move if we need to, and it allows us to save a little more for the future—like when Clara finishes her nursing program and we start thinking about having children. It's not ideal, but it's what works for us right now.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Santiago Martinez: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, depending on the season and what was going on in our lives. In the winter, for example, our heating bill went up quite a bit because the apartment isn't very well insulated, and we had a particularly cold spell. We had to use the space heater more often, which added to the cost. Then there was the summer, when we had to pay more for electricity because we were using the air conditioner almost nonstop. But the biggest fluctuation was around the time Clara started her nursing program. She needed to buy a lot of textbooks, lab supplies, and even a stethoscope, which was an unexpected expense. We also had to pay for her bus passes and some extra meals when she was studying late into the night. On the other hand, during the holidays, we kept our spending in check—no big dinners out or expensive gifts. We focused on what really mattered: spending time together, cooking at home, and keeping our budget as tight as possible. It's been a learning experience, but I think we've gotten better at anticipating these changes and planning for them.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and faith have been a source of strength and support in my life. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they have sacrificed and how deeply they care for one another, even in the face of challenges. Maria has always been my anchor, and seeing how she balances her teaching job with helping Clara with her nursing studies shows the kind of resilience and love that defines our family. Clara, too, has grown into a strong and compassionate person, and I take pride in watching her develop into someone who will make a difference in the world. My parents, though they still face their own struggles, continue to show their pride in what we've built together, and that means more to me than I can put into words. When I spoke about my faith and spirituality, I was reminded of how important it is to have a sense of purpose and connection to something greater than myself. Reverend Thompson and my church community have been a source of guidance and comfort, especially during difficult times. I also reflected on how I choose not to rely on social media for support, and how I find more meaning in real-life connections, whether it's through family, friends, or my faith. These conversations have helped me see that my strength comes from the people I love and the values I hold close to my heart, and I'm grateful for every moment of support and love that has shaped my journey.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Santiago Martinez: I try to save as much as I can, even if it's just a little each month. Right now, we have a small savings account that we contribute to regularly—usually around $100 a month, which might not seem like much, but it adds up over time. I've learned that saving isn't just about having a big emergency fund; it's also about building a sense of security for the future. For example, we've been setting money aside for Clara's nursing license exam, which is going to be a big expense. I also try to save for unexpected things, like car repairs or medical costs, just in case. I know that not everyone has the luxury of saving, and I'm grateful that we've been able to manage our budget in a way that allows us to put something aside. It's not perfect, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that we're not completely at the mercy of every financial setback that comes our way.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Santiago Martinez: For me, saving has been a mix of both—preparing for the future and setting aside money for unexpected things. In the last year, a big part of our savings has gone toward Clara's nursing license exam, which is a significant expense, and we've also been saving for a down payment on a car, something I think will be important as she starts her career. At the same time, we've been building up a small emergency fund, just in case something unexpected comes up, like a medical bill or a sudden repair. I've always believed that saving is about more than just money—it's about having control over your life, even in uncertain times. It's not about being rich, but about being prepared. I know we're not where we want to be financially, but every little bit we save is a step toward a more stable future, not just for me and Maria, but for Clara too. It's a long road, but I'm proud of how we've been managing it.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Santiago Martinez: My occupation is a financial analyst, and it's been the foundation of my journey here in Newark. As a financial analyst, my main responsibilities include analyzing financial data, preparing reports, and helping clients make informed investment decisions. I spend a lot of time looking at market trends, evaluating risks, and figuring out the best strategies for growth. One of the most important parts of my job is understanding the needs of my clients and making sure they feel confident in the decisions we make together. I also work closely with other departments, like risk management and portfolio planning, to ensure everything aligns with our goals. What I've come to appreciate most about this role is how it combines logic with real-world impact. Every number I analyze, every report I prepare, it all ties back to people's lives—whether it's helping a small business owner expand or ensuring a retiree's savings are secure. It's not always glamorous, but I find purpose in knowing that my work contributes to someone's future. And honestly, it's also a way for me to give back, in my own way, to the community that helped me when I first arrived in the U.S. with nothing but a dream and a lot of determination.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Santiago Martinez: I usually work around 55 to 60 hours a week, depending on the time of year and how many projects we're handling. It's not uncommon for the hours to stretch into the evenings, especially when we're preparing reports or dealing with market fluctuations. I've gotten used to it, but it's not without its challenges. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, but I remind myself that this work is more than just a job—it's a way to support my family, help Clara with her future, and give back to the community that gave me a second chance. I've learned to manage my time as best as I can, and I try to make sure I still have moments for rest, reflection, and being with the people I love. It's a balance, but one I'm willing to keep for as long as it takes.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Santiago Martinez: Actually, yes, I did have more than one job for a while, especially in the early years after we moved to Newark. I was working two part-time jobs to help support my family while I was going to night classes at the community college. One job was at a local grocery store, where I worked the late shifts, and the other was as a delivery driver for a small courier service. It was exhausting—sometimes I'd work 12-hour days at the store and then spend the night driving deliveries, all while trying to keep up with my studies. But I knew I had to do it. I remember one night, after a long shift, I was so tired I could barely keep my eyes open, but I still had to finish my homework before going to bed. It wasn't easy, but those jobs taught me a lot about responsibility, time management, and the value of hard work. Eventually, I was able to focus on one job and finish my degree, but those early years were a big part of who I am today.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my daily life, financial responsibilities, and emotional well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come in learning to balance work, family, and self-care. I used to think that pushing through without rest was the only way to succeed, but now I see that taking time to breathe, journal, and connect with Maria and my family is just as important. It also made me think about how we manage our finances—how every dollar we save, every expense we track, and every sacrifice we make is part of building a better future for Clara and our family. I've come to accept that life isn't about perfection, but about showing up every day with intention, even when it's hard. These conversations have reminded me that I'm not just surviving—I'm growing, and I'm doing it with the support of the people I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Santiago Martinez: In total, our household made roughly around $5,200 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary as a financial analyst, Maria's income from teaching, and the occasional freelance work I take on in the evenings. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and save a little for the future. I've learned to be careful with every dollar, especially since we're still working toward bigger goals—like Clara finishing her nursing program and eventually starting her own career. It's a tight balance, but I know that every bit of income we have is a step toward building something more stable for our family.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Santiago Martinez: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. The benefits that come with the job are pretty standard for a mid-sized firm—health insurance, dental and vision coverage, a 401(k) plan, and a decent amount of paid time off. I get about two weeks of vacation each year, plus sick days and holidays. The health benefits have been especially important for me, especially since I've had to deal with that back pain flare-up in the past. It's reassuring to know that I can see a doctor without worrying about the cost, and that my family is also covered under the plan. I also appreciate the flexibility they offer—sometimes, when I need to adjust my schedule to help Clara with her studies or attend a family event, they're understanding. It's not a perfect job, but it's given me stability, and that's something I'm truly grateful for.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Santiago Martinez: My relationships at work have been mostly positive, though they've evolved over the years. When I first started, I was pretty quiet, trying to focus on learning the ropes and not making any mistakes. But as I grew more confident in my role, I started to build stronger connections with my coworkers. My manager, Sarah, has been pretty supportive—she's given me opportunities to take on more responsibility and has always been open to feedback. I think she sees potential in me, and that means a lot. As for my coworkers, some of them have become good friends. We have lunch breaks together, and we often talk about everything from work challenges to our personal lives. There's a sense of camaraderie, especially during busy times when we're all working late. I've learned that trust and respect are the foundation of any good working relationship, and I try to bring that same level of integrity and kindness to my interactions. I don't think I'd ever be the kind of person who just shows up and leaves—work is more than a job for me, it's part of who I am, and I want to be someone people can count on.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Santiago Martinez: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there are definitely moments when it becomes less flexible. I usually start at 7:15 a.m. and work until around 8 or 9 p.m., depending on how busy the day is. Mondays and Fridays tend to be a bit lighter, while midweek days are often the busiest, especially when we're preparing reports or dealing with market changes. The company does offer some flexibility, which I really appreciate. If I need to leave a little early for a family event or adjust my hours to help Clara with her studies, they're usually understanding. That said, there are times when I have to stay late, and I've learned to manage my time carefully so I can still be there for my family. It's not always easy balancing work and personal life, but I've come to accept that this is just part of the rhythm of my life here in Newark.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Santiago Martinez: Overall, I feel like we're in a good place financially, even if it's not where I imagined I'd be at this stage in my life. We've worked hard to build a stable foundation, and I know that stability is something not everyone has. I'm proud of how Maria and I have managed our budget, especially with Clara's education being such a big expense. It's not always easy—there are days when I worry about whether we're saving enough or if we're stretching ourselves too thin—but I also know that we're making progress. I've come to accept that financial security isn't about having everything, but about having enough to provide for the people I love and to keep moving forward. I'm not rich, but I'm not struggling either, and that gives me a sense of peace. I know there's still a long way to go, but I believe that with hard work, smart choices, and the support of my family and community, we can build something even better for the future.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial responsibilities and daily life have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about how our bills fluctuate with the seasons and life events reminded me of the challenges of managing a budget in a place like Newark, where every dollar counts. It also made me think about how we've learned to adapt—whether it's preparing for colder months, saving for Clara's nursing license exam, or setting aside money for unexpected expenses. I've come to accept that financial stability isn't about perfection, but about making smart choices and being prepared for what life throws our way. These conversations also reminded me of how much I value the support of my family and the small sacrifices we make for each other. It's not always easy, but I'm proud of how we've managed to keep our heads above water and keep moving forward, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Santiago Martinez: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were quite different. My father worked as a mechanic at a local garage, and he was always the first one in and the last one out. He didn't have much formal education, but he had a natural talent for fixing things, and he took pride in his work. He worked at least 40 hours a week, sometimes more, especially when the garage was busy. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a nurse at a small clinic in Lisbon. She didn't have a college degree, but she had years of experience and a deep sense of responsibility. She worked long shifts, often 12 hours a day, and she always made sure that the patients were taken care of, even if it meant staying late. Both of them worked hard to provide for our family, and I remember watching them sacrifice so much for us. They never complained, even when times were tough. It's one of the reasons I value education and hard work so much—it's something they taught me through their own lives.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Santiago Martinez: My father's job as a mechanic was more than just fixing cars—it was about solving problems and making things work again. He would spend hours under the hood, diagnosing issues, replacing parts, and making sure every vehicle left the garage running smoothly. His most important duties were ensuring the safety of the drivers and maintaining the reputation of the garage. He had a way of making people feel at ease, even when their car was broken down and they were worried about getting to work. My mother, as a nurse, had a completely different kind of responsibility. Her most important activities were caring for patients, listening to their concerns, and providing comfort when they needed it most. She would stay late if someone was in pain or if a patient needed extra attention. I remember seeing her come home exhausted but always with a smile, because she believed she was making a difference. Their work wasn't glamorous, but it was meaningful, and it taught me that no job is too small if it helps someone else.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Santiago Martinez: My father worked at a small family-owned garage in Lisbon, and it was more than just a place to fix cars—it was a place where people came to feel safe and supported. The garage was run by my uncle, who had started it years before, and my father took over after he retired. It was a modest business, but it had a good reputation in the neighborhood. They fixed everything from cars to motorcycles, and sometimes even did some plumbing or electrical work if they had the tools. My mother worked at a small clinic that served the local community, mostly elderly patients and families who couldn't afford private healthcare. She didn't have a lot of resources, but she always made sure that her patients felt seen and heard. She would stay late if needed, and she never turned anyone away, even if it meant working for free. Both of them were part of something bigger than themselves—they were helping people, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Santiago Martinez: A few years from now, I hope to be in a place where I can look back and know that I did everything I could to build a better life for my family. I hope Clara has finished her nursing program, passed her license exam, and is working in a hospital where she can make a real difference in people's lives. I hope Maria and I have started a family of our own, maybe with one or two children who are growing up in a home filled with love, laughter, and the same kind of values my parents taught me. I hope we're still living in Newark, but maybe in a bigger apartment, or even a small house if the timing is right. I hope I'm still working in finance, but not just for the money—maybe I'll have the chance to mentor others, to give back in the way that so many people gave back to me when I first arrived here. I hope I'm still running a few times a week, still going to church with my family, and still cooking those meals that remind me of home. Most of all, I hope I'm still here, still fighting for a better tomorrow, not just for myself, but for everyone who believes in the power of hard work, love, and second chances.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Santiago Martinez: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who have stood by me through every challenge and celebrated every small victory with me. My parents, Maria, Clara, and the friends and neighbors who have helped me along the way—they are the foundation of everything I have. I value the strength it takes to keep going, even when life feels heavy, and the courage to believe in a better future, no matter how uncertain it seems. I also value the lessons I've learned from my struggles—the resilience, the patience, and the understanding that no one achieves success alone. I value the simple things, too: the smell of my mother's cooking, the sound of rain on the window, the quiet moments with Maria when we don't need to say anything. Most of all, I value the belief that no matter where you come from or what obstacles you face, you can build a life that matters, as long as you have the will to keep going.
